The question of this article is why Obama is down despite some good numbers. You missed that.
When Barry was riding high in the polls, you were arguing just the opposite of what you argue now.  QED.

Douthat conflates context with substance and confuses both, but that's the nature of horse-race-based political punditry.  Since nothing in this piece convincing argues Obama's performance on the merits, pronouncements of his so-called failures being the cause of poll numbers is highly speculative, to say the least.  The Obama administration has its problems, to be sure, but to reduce an analysis of the president's performance to a liberal vs. conservative popularity contest illuminates little.

Establishing a national health care system was a visionary project, except for the fact that all the other democracies already had one and not one of them would trade for the insane system deluded opponents to Obamacare called the best health care system in the world. The dogs barked and still bark, as we see here, but the caravan moved on.

I agree that significant themes have failed to surface in the 2014 election campaign.  And yet, the race is the most expensive ever recorded.  An inescapable conclusion is that America is being drowned in a meaningless sea of advertising while the governance suffers. Sad, very sad.

That letter had continuing repercussions.  Dr. Simon could not put the genie back in the lamp.  Certainly professors of medicine and their subordinates are human with all the frailties that entails.  Years ago such behavior would simply have been seen as obnoxious and dismissed as "boys will be boys."  Now we recognize the misuses of sexual advances and the awkward, career-impacting damage due to the power differential in such cases. It is furthermore awkward to adjudicate.  What a story!  These kinds of things are continuing to happen.  I wonder how many cases of sexual harassment and hostile or unfair work environments go unreported.

Not sure I would use quite as harsh rhetorical flourishes as Dave, but basically I agree with this analysis.  Three quarters of the populace are dissatisfied with the direction of the country, but they want it to change only in ways they approve.  In other words, they don't want a candidate to demonstrate vision, only allegiance to their parochial interests. ("Keep the government's hands off my Social Security!", but by extension, someone else's benefits are fair game.)  The parties are not equally at fault in promoting that mindset.  Republicans spend lots of money cultivating it.  Democrats, unfortunately, do not have a compelling response and so are forced to play the same game most of the time.  In the end, though, voters in this era do not want a vision for the country. That's why congressional candidates don't present one and then list the legislation that will realize it.  Ernst and Braley trip over themselves trying to prove who is more Iowan, with hardly a nod to the fact that they are both American and are vying for a U.S. Senate seat.  Sen. King flirts with voting with the GOP next January, saying he'll decide based on what's best for Maine, forgetting he too is a US senator and not governor of his home state any more.

Bruni lately has become adept at churning out columns of doom without the slightest hint of how the darkness can be reversed.  He seems to blame most of the malaise on politicians of both parties and Obama in particular.  But he forgets that it is ordinary voters who put the clowns and the 1 percenters in office, that is the few who even vote in midterm elections. If one carefully studies polls on various topics, one can see that people are alternately uninformed or misinformed (only 39 percent know that Republicans control the House), hideously selfish, fearful without cause (think Ebola and immigration), bigoted (how else can you explain the hatred of Obama, the threats on his life, and the false beliefs about his birth place?), and generally just confused and full of cognitive dissonance.  A recent study showed that the general populace is more extreme in their views (left and right) than the average politician of either party.  So Frank, what's your solution to Pogo famous observation?

Your comment is utter drivel. In fact, your problem is that Democrat propaganda is threadbare and no longer persuades the uninformed.

BTW, your and Barry's propaganda is just to disparage those who disagree with you and him. To argue that his propaganda machine can't be effective because the R's could counter it, is just circular nonsense.

I agree.

Obama hasn't "lost America". He has lost the portion of the population that think:

- Ebola has killed more Americans than AIDS

- The healthcare.gov website is still down

- More Americans died in Benghazi than on 9/11

- The Secret Service failed to protect the President

- Obama took more vacation days than Bush.

- Unemployment was lower when Reagan was President

- Noriega was a bigger enemy to America than Bin Laden

- Not opening the Keystone pipeline caused gas prices to jump to $5 a gallon

- The stock market is not at all time highs, because Obama hates businesses.

These are the same geniuses that knew Saddam had nu-kew-ler weapons aimed at us and that we were going to be greeted as liberators.

Obama's unpopularity is due mainly to the steady drumbeat of Republican propaganda. People who do not follow politics closely figure that where there is so much smoke there must be some fire. They cannot conceive that the Republican party has nothing except tax cuts and clever one-line slogans to offer.

Now it is perhaps Obama's fault that he has not looked for new ways to counter this propaganda. But it is difficult to counter propaganda if a main point of the propaganda is that the other side should not be listened to except to figure out what nefarious schemes it is up to. An Obama propaganda offensive would give Republicans new opportunities to brand him as socialist and as an uppity person of color.

Yes, it is high time to stop exploiting children, a seeming lucrative abuse that goes unpunished, with Backpage one of the culprits peddling immunity. How do you stop a crime so heinous when solicitations for sex trafficking are so common? Screening software is a start. More attention paid by police a must. Family problems, illegal drugs, even poverty, are powerful inducements  for maintaining the status quo of this shameful practice.

Our House of Representatives, regardless of whether it's controlled by a Democrat or Republican majority, is nearly a dictatorship of that majority. The Speaker gets to decide what is considered.

In the current session 16% of bills waiting to be considered were sponsored by a Democrat and just half of those were of importance. The others regarded issues the Speaker's party was also for or wasn't concerned about.

Of 570 bills passed by our House 74% were non-controversial; just 142 were signed into law by the President. Most of those weren't "law" but "statements."

The House has passed 7 appropriation bills, the Senate Appropriations committee 12, and the full Senate none.

Nearly 4 dozen of the bills passed by our House were votes to repeal Affordable Care.

To propose anything substantive as a candidate is to invite political assassination by one media outlet or another.

And here, in the real world? We're told by our civil engineers that among our peers we have infrastructure that deserves a D+ grade and we need $3.6 trillion of investment in it.

But no new taxes!

ISIS is threatening to topple governments in the Middle East; Iraq, that we spent several hundred thousand lives on, including 4,488 of our own, and over a trillion dollars on, is in worse shape than when it was ruled by that other guy we were told had to be gotten rid of.

The U.S. has the feeling of Depression era politics; everyone distrusts everyone and some guy named Hitler is rising in Europe.
.

Big ideas require our politicians a commitment to work together to make them happen. The defining principle behind politicians today is to get elected or reelected. For Republicans require their ideas to be as small as possible to fit the small and backward ideas of their base. for Democratts it has been nothing but defensive tactics especially in Senate races especially where Republican small ideas prevail

Gerrymandering and rules restricting voting are what matter and someone who fights against the stream with a big idea is bound to get shot down. Our political system favors big backroom money, the protection of the status quo and the media which favors splashy, but shallow stories.

At certain times in our history especially at the times of the Roosevelts and after the death of President Kennedy our public saw the need to come together against big money interests and inequality of all kinds. Now we are lost in a thicket of animosity and accusations that hide the machinations of big money and racism.

Big ideas? Perhaps a constitutional convention to Undo Citizens United, unfair voting rules and the way we create House districts might be a start, but don't hold your breath.

I worked at a hospital (I shall not name) as a technician.  I was horribly bullied by a doctor and reported it to my supervisor.  She insisted I write up the incident immediately.  It turned out he had also bullied several nurses.  He was sanctioned and soon left the hospital service.  He eventually sent me, and others, a letter of apology.  His behavior, however, was also unacceptable to the doctors. His behavior damaged his career rather than that of his subordinates.  I always felt totally supported at that hospital.  I have worked at other institutions and none were even slightly as supportive of their nursing, social service and technical staff.  This was just one of many instances of the helpful treatment I received from my superiors whenever there was a problem of any kind.  It proved to me that a truly good work environment can exist.  I have also worked at a prestigious teaching hospital where the atmosphere was often dog-eat-dog vicious.
Repubs were obstructionist because Obama's ideas are absurd. illegal aliens? Ebola?  these are failures.

Right track-wrong track is bogus. One person wants a law against abortion. Failing to get one she thinks the country is on the wrong track. Another person. wants an increase in the minimum wage. Failing to get one he thinks the county is on the wrong track..An individual thinks that we should send troops to Iraq, someone else is unhappy with Fed policies, another cannot get a home loan, someone else has been denied food stamps, another is unhappy with the farm bill. and so it goes on and on. each of these people thinks the government is on the wrong track. Regardless of the party in power or the occupant of the oval office there will always be about 70 percent of the people who believe the government is on the wrong track.
Except for me.....I know it is on the wrong track.

The Republicans have run an agenda-free campaign--hoping that magic combination of disapproval of the President, the history of the President's party suffering in the sixth year elections, a midterm electorate that leans older, whiter and more conservartive--with a heaping helping of gerrymandering and voter suppression will carry them to victory.

They never tire of pointing the right track/wrong track number as favoring them--never once acknowledging that there is scant evidence to support the notion that that means the people who are saying we're on the wrong track are in favor of a more conservative track.

If anything, polling on the major policy issues facing the nation suggest the opposite--the GOP's position on almost every major issue is at odds with what majorities--on some issues--sizable majorities want.

The GOP can't run on what they want to do--to Social Security, Medicare, minimum wages or climate change.

If the public is dispirited about BOTH parties--it is because they've lost confidence in the ability of the Democrats to do what they say they want to do.

The last four years of Republican obstructionism is at the root of it.

Why isn't Obama a judgment on what you believe???  In fact, he is the incarnation of what you believe  --  the problem is, what you believe just doesn't work and is as much a failure as he is.  At least have the decency to admit your own failure and not distance yourself from your former savior.

" It’s a problem of leadership that reflects badly on liberalism but doesn’t necessarily vindicate conservatism." NOBODY I know -- (and that's mostly liberal-minded people) isn't disappointed with Obama. He isn't a judgment on what we believe, he's a judgment on himself.

It's exceedingly rare that I agree with a Douthat column, but I agree with much of this one. A majority of Americans think that the country is going in the wrong direction and, rightly or wrongly, they blame President Obama.

With middle-income Americans still in shaky economic times, with ISIS threatening the Middle East, and with Ebola on our shores there's plenty to worry about and the president is a convenient target.

For my part, I think that Obama has handled ISIS cautiously but reasonably, feel that the Affordable Care Act has done more good than not (although I would have preferred a single payer program), and blame Republican intransigence on Republicans. My key complaint with the Obama Administration is that it bailed out Wall Street, but did a lackluster job for Main Street. Ordinary Americans are still feeling the fallout from 2008, although I agree that the economy is healing slowly.

At the same time, it's easy to lay our troubles at the president's feet, and that impulse may bode well for the Republican Party on Tuesday. I'll be hoping, though, that sufficient voters see things my way to keep Democratic control of the Senate.

Perhaps we get the government we deserve. We do not want to do the tedious detail work necessary to tell if a politician or a party is telling the truth or getting the facts straight. We let the parties bombard us with ads that insult our intelligence while trying to press our, or someone's buttons, rather than insisting on an in-depth confrontation with an issue from which we might learn something.

People may dislike the same old same old, but most of them know that most differences from the same old would be worse. Most alternatives to a flaky PC involve a blue screen or a failure to boot at all. When the flakiness persists, the alternative of defenestration becomes attractive even though it does no good. Much of the Republican appeal is at bottom the appeal of defenestration. Throwing the present government out the window (or drowning it in the bathtub) is an emotionally attractive idea, like quitting an unpleasant job. But the next morning the problems are still there.

The biggest changes in trick-or-treating have come from society's growing sense of danger. The cookie chapter of the original 1950 Betty Crocker's Picture Cookbook suggested some recipes as appropriate for "tricks-or-treats for Halloween" (no apostrophe). Children trick-or-treated in the evening with no adult accompaniment.  The only danger I ever ran into was from a neighbor who made himself a one-man vigilante to rid the building of Puerto Rican kids. (He mistook me for one).

I'm encouraged that Ropes and Gray has taken this case. It's great for people do to any type of pro bono work in this economy, and they have a really strong record. It suggests that this is more than doing a good deed or making a statement to raise awareness. I'm hoping this means they believe this case is very, very strong; winnable. It should be. "Perfected a business model" is exactly right, and so is going for damages and injunctions without seeking to shut down the whole transparently exploitative, repulsive enterprise. It would make a far stronger statement to have them go out of business when they lose their bread and butter; innocent children. Words fail me.
Couple that with a class in basic notions of personal honor and integrity.

Our President is black.  Our president’s ideology exists on a point on the political spectrum. There are people not at that particular position.  You then conclude that the only rational explanation is those people are racist as defined by their position on the political spectrum not by the traditional understanding of racism as prejudice against certain races.  By redefining racism you have made Mr. Obama’s race irrelevant because racism is now a political ideology.  If Mr. Obama is a centrist then Elizabeth Warren on the left and Ted Cruz on the right are equally racists.

The American economic recovery is far ahead of what is happening in Europe and Japan. With a democrat in office and a democratic Congress there was continued stimulus, not enough, but the austerity tack that the republicans chose was held in abeyance until 2010 when the anti-government party regained Congress, threatened to shut down the government over the debt ceiling and eventually misled this country into a disaster known as the sequester which willy -nilly destroyed programs necessary to a continued recovery and necessary to common human need. Both of these factors were ignored by the  party that caters exclusively to the wealthy and the corporate elite. Despite the obstructive republican tactics and a refusal by the House of Representatives to work with a centrist president that has been called the most radical in history, the country is moving forward. What would the current GOP have considered real progressives like FDR and LBJ ? The only rational conclusion that can be drawn from all of this is that the racism in this country is overwhelming common sense. Nothing that Obama has done can be considered extreme. The wasp's nest in the Middle East should have been left strictly alone in the first place. In some thirteen years of so called war. absolutely nothing has been accomplished and we should leave these countries that are still enmeshed in 15th century theological violence to their own devices. Turning the Senate over to the Brothers Koch is not the answer.
Every penny of government spending is somebody's income. Politics is the fight over that.
I stand with Steve.

And Every penny of Government spending is first removed from a taxpayer's pocket thus reducing THEIR income. It would be a zero-sum game except that the Government spends the money on things the original owner doesn't want to pay for and so the marginal utility of that spending is decreased. Government spending makes society as a whole poorer.

It has been my experience that people grow more conservative
as they grow older and see how little they get for their taxes and how
'less than little' politicians do for them. I do not know the demographic
numbers on "Hipsters" but perhaps a significant number are entering
their thirties and starting to raise families and begin to really wonder
what do they get for the taxes...all I get is large potholes, students
dropping out and failing mis-functioning schools and more and more
convicts on the streets.

I don't think we will see: Goldwater - Now, more than Ever !
stickers soon but the days of LBJ and massive Social Impactive Laws
and the money to support them are long, long gone.

Perhaps our style of Government cannot provide for the nation anymore.
Perhaps the two party fascist - in the Italian sense -
way of governing is beyond all repair.

I don't know...what I do know is the one party state of China,
as ruthless as it is - aims to rule the world economically
while we twiddle our political and economic thumbs.

This is just his flowery way of saying if she sleeps with him she can get promotions.  That is classic sexual harassment.  Was she not entitled to advancement without his sweaty hands and mouth on her body? Ick.

Well, they are businesses but are supposed to be more than "just" businesses.  They are supposed to be institutions that develop the minds and characters of our most talented and smart human beings.  Sometimes, obviously, there are conflicting values.
Business is by definition a 'chance' - but I guess if you haven't started one or run one you wouldn't know : )

Businesses took over what artists used to do. When editors found stunning new writers in the past, they nurtured them, sometimes through several books that didn't sell well. Now an editor asks how many twitter followers do you have before deciding to publish a book. Big business took over the pop music industry. Now we have singers who don't have to sing--they just autotune the voice. The singer only has to look good and be able to lip sync. Fashion follows the same pattern. Movies are even worse. It may be Marvel Comic movies from now on. Artists take chances. Business people don't. And business has taken over the art world.

Kind of a bad decision to make about an entire profession and career path based on the pettiness of a few professors. If they were committed to their careers they should have moved to another group, dept. or institution.

Unfortunately, so long as the Dean and the Provost remain in their positions, Dr. Giodano will have little chance in getting tenure at Yale, as these men have discretionary authority to approve any promotion.  Indeed, any faculty member who spoke out against them would face a higher chance of being  retaliated against if they remained in their positions.
